instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.CD3125: What is CD3125? This is a common typo,  the person typing CD3125 was most likely referring to CD3215.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has no power. The ampmeter stays black, and I have no <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_E85</SIGNAL> nither <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85_SS</SIGNAL> voltages. Nither seams to be shorted (0.555 on diode reading).

F4700 seams to be ok.

Already tried a known good DCIN cable, with same result.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Start checking diode mode to ground on CC1/2 lines.
Also compare the value at <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL> with good board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Diode readings:

<SIGNAL>E85_CC1</SIGNAL> = 0.554
<SIGNAL>E85_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.014

I don't have a good board of this model, but it seams that CC2 is shorted. Shall i inject voltage on it, or replace <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>??

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Is not pure short, to heat something there.
Replace the chip, is classic issue.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I've replace <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>, and the short on CC2 has gone (0.555 on diode reading). However, I have the same behavier.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL>.
May need to change <CHIP>U4780</CHIP> and/or <CHIP>U4701</CHIP> too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Diode on  <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL> = 0.333

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Looks too low.
Change <CHIP>U4780</CHIP> first.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
I've replaced  <CHIP>U4780</CHIP> and  <CHIP>U4701</CHIP>, but same behavier. Diode on  <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL>  is 0.329.
I notice now that <CAPACITOR>C4750</CAPACITOR> <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85_SS</SIGNAL> seams to be a bit oxidized and corroded. It wasen't shorted, but i removed.  Can it be related?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Diode mode on <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL> should be higher than 0.400.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Replaced again <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> but same thing. 
There are a lot of components with  <SIGNAL>3V0_AON</SIGNAL>. Shal I inject some voltage to figure out if something gets hotter?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Voltage injection cannot help here.

<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip used is good for sure?
Check diode mode to ground on its LDOs.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Sorry, for the stupid question, but what <CHIP>CD3125</CHIP>? I can't find it on this board

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Sorry for error; there was another thread with 00244 board.

You may have problem with <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> in this case.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Sorry, but I can't find it also. I replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, but same result. No power

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, is true.
What is actual diode mode to ground for <SIGNAL>3V_AON</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Diode on  <SIGNAL>PP3VR3V0_AON</SIGNAL>  = 0.324

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Still low value.
Some chip must be affected there.
Try another <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Replaced other <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> but same result. 
<SIGNAL>PP3VR3V0_AON</SIGNAL>  = 0.328

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
You don't get any voltage at F4700?
What voltage do you get at CC1/2 lines?
Did you try another charger?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi,
I didn't read CC1/2 voltages, but I get 0V at F4700, and have tried 2 different chargers and cable connectors.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>E85_CC1</SIGNAL>= 0V
<SIGNAL>E85_CC2</SIGNAL> = 0.166V

Do you think that can be something shorted on a J4700 line? Do you have the resistance to ground of those pins on J4700?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Revert cable connection and check again.
CC1/2 lines change their function.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hi,
With reverse conection, I get reverse values:

CC1 = 0.186V
CC2 = 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: You need to compare readings with known good board...
